true.say: Hello, are you currently working with the “Intro to Research” professor?
true.page: I am, I'm one of her research assistants.
true.say: I'm interested in becoming one too!
true.page: Oh, that’s ambitious...
Especially for a freshman like you!
true.say: True, true... But I’m willing to put the time and effort.
I really want to get involved, and I’ve been trying to email professors asking for positions.
true.page: Let me guess, no luck?
That's fairly common.
Well, I can only speak from my own experience.
I actually didn’t get a research position until my third year.
So yeah, patience is a key here. But let me tell you what I did right that I did wrong my first two years.
First of all, if you’re emailing them, keep it professional. You know how to send email right?
Perfect.
Second, show them your skills, experience, and capabilities. Now this is a bit tricky in your case, since you literally just got here.
I never said that! Actually, there were two students when I got my first research position. The second student was actually freshman!

option.say: Don’t tell me she’s the professor’s daughter...

true.page: You'd think...
She didn't have any previous experience but her passion was convincing enough to get the professor to select her!
The student showed her seriousness and how much she was willing to work.
Also, sometimes some professors actually likes hiring freshman.
It allows for professors to have more time to train the students.
If they stay longer, by the time they’re junior, they have both the skills and a deeper knowledge of the professor's work.
That can actually save tons of time for preparation!
Now you do!
true.say: Thank you so much! I really appreciate it! You brightened my day!
true.page: Sure thing. Keep going. Don’t give up!
